On the Secrecy Capacity of Fading Channels

Praveen Kumar Gopala, Lifeng Lai and Hesham El Gamal
Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
The Ohio State University
Columbus, OH 43210
Email: {gopalap,lail,helgamal}@ece.osu.edu
Abstract

We consider the secure transmission of information over an ergodic fading channel in the presence of an eavesdropper. Our eavesdropper can be viewed as the wireless counterpart of Wynerâ€™s wiretapper. The secrecy capacity of such a system is characterized under the assumption of asymptotically long coherence intervals. We first consider the full Channel State Information (CSI) case, where the transmitter has access to the channel gains of the legitimate receiver and the eavesdropper. The secrecy capacity under this full CSI assumption serves as an upper bound for the secrecy capacity when only the CSI of the legitimate receiver is known at the transmitter, which is characterized next. In each scenario, the perfect secrecy capacity is obtained along with the optimal power and rate allocation strategies. We then propose a low-complexity on/off power allocation strategy that achieves near-optimal performance with only the main channel CSI. More specifically, this scheme is shown to be asymptotically optimal as the average SNR goes to infinity, and interestingly, is shown to attain the secrecy capacity under the full CSI assumption. Remarkably, our results reveal the positive impact of fading on the secrecy capacity and establish the critical role of rate adaptation, based on the main channel CSI, in facilitating secure communications over slow fading channels.

1 Introduction

The notion of information-theoretic secrecy was first introduced by Shannon [1]. This strong notion of secrecy does not rely on any assumptions on the computational resources of the eavesdropper. More specifically, perfect information-theoretic secrecy requires that Iâ¢(W;Z)=0ğ¼ğ‘Šğ‘0I(W;Z)=0italic_I ( italic_W ; italic_Z ) = 0, i.e., the signal Zğ‘Zitalic_Z received by the eavesdropper does not provide any additional information about the transmitted message Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. Shannon considered a scenario where both the legitimate receiver and the eavesdropper have direct access to the transmitted signal. Under this model, he proved a negative result implying that the achievability of perfect secrecy requires the entropy of the private key Kğ¾Kitalic_K, used to encrypt the message Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, to be larger than or equal to the entropy of the message itself (i.e., Hâ¢(K)â‰¥Hâ¢(W)ğ»ğ¾ğ»ğ‘ŠH(K)\geq H(W)italic_H ( italic_K ) â‰¥ italic_H ( italic_W ) for perfect secrecy). However, it was later shown by Wyner in [2] that this negative result was a consequence of the over-restrictive model used inÂ [1]. Wyner introduced the wiretap channel which accounts for the difference in the two noise processes, as observed by the destination and wiretapper. In this model, the wiretapper has no computational limitations and is assumed to know the codebook used by the transmitter. Under the assumption that the wiretapperâ€™s signal is a degraded version of the destinationâ€™s signal, Wyner characterized the tradeoff between the information rate to the destination and the level of ignorance at the wiretapper (measured by its equivocation), and showed that it is possible to achieve a non-zero secrecy capacity. This work was later extended to non-degraded channels by CsiszaÂ´Â´ğ‘\acute{a}overÂ´ start_ARG italic_a end_ARGr and KÃ¶rner [3], where it was shown that if the main channel is less noisy or more capable than the wiretapper channel, then it is possible to achieve a non-zero secrecy capacity.

More recently, the effect of slow fading on the secrecy capacity was studied in [8, 9]. In these works, it is assumed that the fading is quasi-static which leads to an alternative definition of outage probability, wherein secure communications can be guaranteed only for the fraction of time when the main channel is stronger than the channel seen by the eavesdropper. This performance metric appears to have an operational significance only in delay sensitive applications with full Channel State Information (CSI). The absence of CSI sheds doubt on the operational significance of outage-based secrecy since it limits the ability of the source to know which parts of the message are decoded by the eavesdropper. In this paper, we focus on delay-tolerant applications which allow for the adoption of an ergodic version of the slow fading channel, instead of the outage-based formulation. Quite interestingly, we show in the sequel that, under this model, one can achieve a perfectly secure non-zero rate even when the eavesdropper channel is more capable then the legitimate channel on the average. In particular, our work here characterizes the secrecy capacity of the slow fading channel in the presence of an eavesdropper [10]. Our eavesdropper is the wireless counterpart of Wynerâ€™s wiretapper. We first assume that the transmitter knows the CSI of both the legitimate and eavesdropper channels, and derive the optimal power allocation strategy that achieves the secrecy capacity. Next we consider the case where the transmitter only knows the legitimate channel CSI and, again, derive the optimal power allocation strategy. We then propose an on/off power transmission scheme, with variable rate allocation, which approaches the optimal performance for asymptotically large average SNR. Interestingly, this scheme is also shown to attain the secrecy capacity under the full CSI assumption which implies that, at high SNR values, the additional knowledge of the eavesdropper CSI does not yield any gains in terms of the secrecy capacity for slow fading channels. Finally, our theoretical and numerical results are used to argue that rate adaptation plays a more critical role than power control in achieving the secrecy capacity of slow fading channels. This observation contrasts the scenario without secrecy constraints, where transmission strategies with constant rate are able to achieve capacityÂ [4].

2 System Model

The system model is illustrated in Fig.Â 1. The source Sğ‘†Sitalic_S communicates with a destination Dğ·Ditalic_D in the presence of an eavesdropper Eğ¸Eitalic_E. During any coherence interval iğ‘–iitalic_i, the signal received by the destination and the eavesdropper are given by, respectively

where gMâ¢(i),gEâ¢(i)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘€ğ‘–subscriptğ‘”ğ¸ğ‘–g_{M}(i),g_{E}(i)italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) are the channel gains from the source to the legitimate receiver (main channel) and the eavesdropper (eavesdropper channel) respectively, and wMâ¢(i),wEâ¢(i)subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘€ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ¸ğ‘–w_{M}(i),w_{E}(i)italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) represent the i.i.d additive Gaussian noise with unit variance at the destination and the eavesdropper respectively. We denote the fading power gains of the main and eavesdropper channels by hMâ¢(i)=|gMâ¢(i)|2subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘€ğ‘–2h_{M}(i)=|g_{M}(i)|^{2}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) = | italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and hEâ¢(i)=|gEâ¢(i)|2subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ¸ğ‘–2h_{E}(i)=|g_{E}(i)|^{2}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) = | italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively. We assume that both channels experience block fading, where the channel gains remain constant during each coherence interval and change independently from one coherence interval to the next. The fading process is assumed to be ergodic with a bounded continuous distribution. Moreover, the fading coefficients of the destination and the eavesdropper in any coherence interval are assumed to be independent of each other. We further assume that the number of channel uses n1subscriptğ‘›1n_{1}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT within each coherence interval is large enough to allow for invoking random coding arguments. As shown in the sequel, this assumption is instrumental in our achievability proofs.

In this paper we consider only perfect secrecy which requires the equivocation rate Resubscriptğ‘…ğ‘’R_{e}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be equal to the message rate. The secrecy capacity Cssubscriptğ¶ğ‘ C_{s}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is defined as the maximum achievable perfect secrecy rate, i.e.,

Csâ¢=Î”â¢supPenâ‰¤ÏµRs.subscriptğ¶ğ‘ Î”subscriptsupremumsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘›italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ C_{s}~{}\overset{\Delta}{=}~{}\sup_{P_{e}^{n}\leq\epsilon}~{}R_{s}~{}.italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overroman_Î” start_ARG = end_ARG roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (3)

Throughout the sequel, we assume that the CSI is known at the destination perfectly. Based on the available CSI, the transmitter adapts its transmission power and rate to maximize the perfect secrecy rate subject to a long-term average power constraint PÂ¯Â¯ğ‘ƒ\bar{P}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG.

3 Full CSI at the Transmitter

Here we assume that at the beginning of each coherence interval, the transmitter knows the channel states of the legitimate receiver and the eavesdropper perfectly. When hMsubscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hEsubscriptâ„ğ¸h_{E}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are both known at the transmitter, one would expect the optimal scheme to allow for transmission only when hM>hEsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸h_{M}>h_{E}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and to adapt the transmitted power according to the instantaneous values of hMsubscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hEsubscriptâ„ğ¸h_{E}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The following result formalizes this intuitive argument.

Theorem 1

When the channel gains of both the legitimate receiver and the eavesdropper are known at the transmitter, the secrecy capacity is given by

such thatÂ ğ”¼â¢{Pâ¢(hM,hE)}â‰¤PÂ¯.such thatÂ ğ”¼ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒ\mbox{such that }\qquad\qquad{\mathbb{E}}\{P(h_{M},h_{E})\}~{}\leq~{}\bar{P}.such that blackboard_E { italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } â‰¤ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG . Proof:Â Â  A detailed proof of achievability and the converse part is provided in the Appendix. Here, we outline the scheme used in the achievability part. The achievable perfect secrecy rate at any instant is then given by [logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM,hE))âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢Pâ¢(hM,hE))]+.superscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸[\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M},h_{E})\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P(h_{M},h_{E})\right)]^{+}.[ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Averaging over all fading realizations, we get the average achievable perfect secrecy rate as

We now derive the optimal power allocation policy that achieves the secrecy capacity under the full CSI assumption. The secrecy capacity is then determined by substituting this optimal power allocation policy for Pâ¢(hM,hE)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸P(h_{M},h_{E})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in (4).

4 Only Main Channel CSI at the Transmitter

In this section, we assume that at the beginning of each coherence interval, the transmitter only knows the CSI of the main channel (legitimate receiver).

4.1 Optimal Power Allocation

We first characterize the secrecy capacity under this scenario in the following theorem.

Theorem 2

When only the channel gain of the legitimate receiver is known at the transmitter, the secrecy capacity is given by

Cs(M)=maxPâ¢(hM)â¢âˆ¬[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM))âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢Pâ¢(hM))]+â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhE,superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘ ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€double-integralsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸C_{s}^{(M)}~{}=~{}\max\limits_{P(h_{M})}\iint\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M})\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P(h_{M})\right)\right]^{+}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}~{},italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_M ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¬ [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (8)
such thatÂ ğ”¼â¢{Pâ¢(hM)}â‰¤PÂ¯.such thatÂ ğ”¼ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘ƒ\mbox{such that }\qquad\qquad{\mathbb{E}}\{P(h_{M})\}~{}\leq~{}\bar{P}.such that blackboard_E { italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } â‰¤ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG . (9)

Proof:Â Â  A detailed proof of achievability and the converse part is provided in the Appendix. Here, we outline the scheme used to show achievability. We use the following variable rate transmission scheme. During a coherence interval with main channel fading state hMsubscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the transmitter transmits codewords at rate logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM))1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€\log(1+h_{M}P(h_{M}))roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) with power Pâ¢(hM)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€P(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). This variable rate scheme relies on the assumption of large coherence intervals and ensures that when hE>hMsubscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{E}>h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the mutual information between the source and the eavesdropper is upper bounded by logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM))1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€\log(1+h_{M}P(h_{M}))roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). When hEâ‰¤hMsubscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{E}\leq h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, this mutual information will be logâ¡(1+hEâ¢Pâ¢(hM))1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€\log(1+h_{E}P(h_{M}))roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). Averaging over all the fading states, the average rate of the main channel is given by

âˆ¬logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM))â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhE,double-integral1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸\iint\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M})\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E},âˆ¬ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

while the information accumulated at the eavesdropper is

âˆ¬logâ¡(1+minâ¡{hM,hE}â¢Pâ¢(hM))â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhE.double-integral1subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸\iint\log\left(1+\min\{h_{M},h_{E}\}P(h_{M})\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}.âˆ¬ roman_log ( 1 + roman_min { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Hence for a given power control policy Pâ¢(hM)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€P(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the achievable perfect secrecy rate is given by

Rs(M)=âˆ¬[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM))âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢Pâ¢(hM))]+â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhE.superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘€double-integralsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸R_{s}^{(M)}~{}=~{}\iint\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M})\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P(h_{M})\right)\right]^{+}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_M ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ¬ [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (10)

One can then optimize over all feasible power control policies Pâ¢(hM)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€P(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to maximize the perfect secrecy rate. Finally, we observe that our secure message is hidden across different fading states (please refer to our proof for more details). â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

We now derive the optimal power allocation policy that achieves the secrecy capacity under the main channel CSI assumption. Similar to TheoremÂ 1, the objective function under this case is also concave, and using the Lagrangian maximization approach for solving (8), we get the following optimality condition.

âˆ‚Rs(M)âˆ‚Pâ¢(hM)=hMâ¢Prâ¢(hEâ‰¤hM)1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM)âˆ’âˆ«0hM(hE1+hEâ¢Pâ¢(hM))â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhEâˆ’Î»=0,superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ‘€Prsubscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptâ„ğ‘€1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€superscriptsubscript0subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸ğœ†0\frac{\partial R_{s}^{(M)}}{\partial P(h_{M})}~{}=~{}\frac{h_{M}\textrm{Pr}\left(h_{E}\leq h_{M}\right)}{1+h_{M}P(h_{M})}-\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\left(\frac{h_{E}}{1+h_{E}P(h_{M})}\right)f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}-\lambda~{}=~{}0,divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_M ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Pr ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG - âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î» = 0 ,

where Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» is a constant that satisfies the power constraint in (9) with equality. For any main channel fading state hMsubscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the optimal transmit power level Pâ¢(hM)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€P(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is determined from the above equation. If the obtained power level turns out to be negative, then the optimal value of Pâ¢(hM)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€P(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is equal to 0. This follows from the concavity of the objective function in (8) w.r.t. Pâ¢(hM)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€P(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The solution to this optimization problem depends on the distributions fâ¢(hM)ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€f(h_{M})italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and fâ¢(hE)ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸f(h_{E})italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). In the following, we focus on the Rayleigh fading scenario with ğ”¼â¢{hM}=Î³Â¯Mğ”¼subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€{\mathbb{E}}\{h_{M}\}=\overline{\gamma}_{M}blackboard_E { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ”¼â¢{hE}=Î³Â¯Eğ”¼subscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸{\mathbb{E}}\{h_{E}\}=\overline{\gamma}_{E}blackboard_E { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in detail. With Rayleigh fading, the objective function in (8) simplifies to

where

Specializing the optimality conditions to the Rayleigh fading scenario, it can be shown that the power level of the transmitter at any fading state hMsubscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is obtained by solving the equation

expâ¡(1Î³Â¯Eâ¢Pâ¢(hM))Î³Â¯Eâ¢(Pâ¢(hM))2â¢[Eiâ¢(1Î³Â¯Eâ¢Pâ¢(hM))âˆ’Eiâ¢(hMÎ³Â¯E+1Î³Â¯Eâ¢Pâ¢(hM))]=0.1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€2delimited-[]Ei1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€Eisubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€0\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\frac{\exp\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}P(h_{M})}\right)}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}(P(h_{M}))^{2}}\left[\textrm{Ei}\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}P(h_{M})}\right)-\textrm{Ei}\left(\frac{h_{M}}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}}+\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}P(h_{M})}\right)\right]~{}=~{}0.divide start_ARG roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG [ Ei ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) - Ei ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) ] = 0 .

If there is no positive solution to this equation for a particular hMsubscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then we set Pâ¢(hM)=0ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€0P(h_{M})=0italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0. The secrecy capacity is then determined by substituting this optimal power allocation policy for Pâ¢(hM)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€P(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in (11).

We observe that, unlike the traditional ergodic fading scenario, achieving the optimal performance under a security constraint relies heavily on using a variable rate transmission strategy. This can be seen by evaluating the performance of a constant rate strategy where a single codeword is interleaved across infinitely many fading realizations. This interleaving will result in the eavesdropper gaining more information, than the destination, when its channel is better than the main channel, thereby yielding a perfect secrecy rate that is strictly smaller than that in (10). It is easy to see that the achievable perfect secrecy rate of the constant rate scheme, assuming a Gaussian codebook, is given by

maxPâ¢(hM)â¢âˆ¬[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM))âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢Pâ¢(hM))]â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhE,subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€double-integraldelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸\max\limits_{P(h_{M})}\iint\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M})\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P(h_{M})\right)\right]f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}~{},roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¬ [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,
such thatÂ ğ”¼â¢{Pâ¢(hM)}â‰¤PÂ¯.such thatÂ ğ”¼ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘ƒ\mbox{such that }\qquad\qquad{\mathbb{E}}\{P(h_{M})\}\leq\bar{P}.such that blackboard_E { italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } â‰¤ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG .

Unlike the two previous optimization problems, the objective function in this optimization problem is not a concave function of Pâ¢(hM)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€P(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Using the Lagrangian formulation, we only get the following necessary KKT conditions for the optimal point.

Î»â‰¥hM1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM)âˆ’âˆ«(hE1+hEâ¢Pâ¢(hM))â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhE,ğœ†subscriptâ„ğ‘€1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸\lambda~{}\geq~{}\frac{h_{M}}{1+h_{M}P(h_{M})}-\int\left(\frac{h_{E}}{1+h_{E}P(h_{M})}\right)f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E},italic_Î» â‰¥ divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG - âˆ« ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,
ğ”¼â¢{Pâ¢(hM)}=PÂ¯.ğ”¼ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘ƒ{\mathbb{E}}\{P(h_{M})\}~{}=~{}\bar{P}.blackboard_E { italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG . (12)

4.2 On/Off Power Control

We now propose a transmission policy wherein the transmitter sends information only when the channel gain of the legitimate receiver hMsubscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT exceeds a pre-determined constant threshold Ï„>0ğœ0\tau>0italic_Ï„ > 0. Moreover, when hM>Ï„subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğœh_{M}>\tauitalic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_Ï„, the transmitter always uses the same power level Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. However, it is crucial to adapt the rate of transmission instantaneously as logâ¡(1+Pâ¢hM)1ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€\log(1+Ph_{M})roman_log ( 1 + italic_P italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with hMsubscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It is clear that for an average power constraint PÂ¯Â¯ğ‘ƒ\bar{P}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG, the constant power level used for transmission will be

P=PÂ¯Prâ¢(hM>Ï„).ğ‘ƒÂ¯ğ‘ƒPrsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğœP~{}=~{}\frac{\bar{P}}{\textrm{Pr}(h_{M}>\tau)}~{}.italic_P = divide start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG Pr ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_Ï„ ) end_ARG .

Using a similar argument as in the achievable part of TheoremÂ 2, we get the perfect secrecy rate achieved by the proposed scheme, using Gaussian inputs, as

Rs(Câ¢P)=âˆ«0âˆâˆ«Ï„âˆ[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢P)âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢P)]+â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhE.superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ¶ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscriptğœsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒ1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸R_{s}^{(CP)}~{}=~{}\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{\tau}^{\infty}\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}P\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P\right)\right]^{+}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}~{}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_P ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Specializing to the Rayleigh fading scenario, we get

P=PÂ¯Prâ¢(hM>Ï„)=PÂ¯â¢e(Ï„/Î³Â¯M),ğ‘ƒÂ¯ğ‘ƒPrsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğœÂ¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€P~{}=~{}\frac{\bar{P}}{\textrm{Pr}(h_{M}>\tau)}~{}=~{}\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}~{},italic_P = divide start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG Pr ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_Ï„ ) end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

and the secrecy capacity simplifies to

Rs(Câ¢P)=âˆ«Ï„âˆâˆ«0hM[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢PÂ¯â¢e(Ï„/Î³Â¯M))âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢PÂ¯â¢e(Ï„/Î³Â¯M))]â¢1Î³Â¯Mâ¢eâˆ’(hM/Î³Â¯M)â¢1Î³Â¯Eâ¢eâˆ’(hE/Î³Â¯E)â¢dhEâ¢dhM,superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ¶ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğœsuperscriptsubscript0subscriptâ„ğ‘€delimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€1subscriptâ„ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€superscriptğ‘’subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸superscriptğ‘’subscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€R_{s}^{(CP)}=\int_{\tau}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}\right)\right]\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}}e^{-(h_{M}/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}}e^{-(h_{E}/\overline{\gamma}_{E})}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}~{},italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_P ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - which then simplifies to

Rs(Câ¢P)=eâˆ’(Ï„/Î³Â¯M)â¢logâ¡(1+Ï„â¢PÂ¯â¢e(Ï„/Î³Â¯M))+expâ¡(1Î³Â¯Mâ¢PÂ¯â¢e(Ï„/Î³Â¯M))â¢Eiâ¢(Ï„Î³Â¯M+1Î³Â¯Mâ¢PÂ¯â¢e(Ï„/Î³Â¯M))superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ¶ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€1ğœÂ¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€EiğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€R_{s}^{(CP)}~{}=~{}e^{-(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}\log\left(1+\tau\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}\right)+\exp\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}}\right)\textrm{Ei}\left(\frac{\tau}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}}+\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}}\right)italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_P ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_Ï„ / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 + italic_Ï„ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) Ei ( divide start_ARG italic_Ï„ end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG )
+expâ¡(1Î³Â¯Eâ¢PÂ¯â¢e(Ï„/Î³Â¯M)âˆ’Ï„Î³Â¯M)â¢[Eiâ¢(Ï„Î³Â¯E+1Î³Â¯Eâ¢PÂ¯â¢e(Ï„/Î³Â¯M))âˆ’Eiâ¢(1Î³Â¯Eâ¢PÂ¯â¢e(Ï„/Î³Â¯M))]1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€delimited-[]EiğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€Ei1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€+\exp\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}}-\frac{\tau}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}}\right)\left[\textrm{Ei}\left(\frac{\tau}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}}+\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}}\right)-\textrm{Ei}\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}}\right)\right]+ roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_Ï„ end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) [ Ei ( divide start_ARG italic_Ï„ end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) - Ei ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) ]
âˆ’expâ¡([1Î³Â¯M+1Î³Â¯E]PÂ¯â¢e(Ï„/Î³Â¯M))â¢Eiâ¢([1Î³Â¯M+1Î³Â¯E]â¢[Ï„+1PÂ¯â¢e(Ï„/Î³Â¯M)]).delimited-[]1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€Eidelimited-[]1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸delimited-[]ğœ1Â¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€-\exp\left(\frac{\left[\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}}+\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}}\right]}{\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}}\right)\textrm{Ei}\left(\left[\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}}+\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}}\right]\left[\tau+\frac{1}{\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}}\right]\right)~{}.- roman_exp ( divide start_ARG [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ] end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) Ei ( [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ] [ italic_Ï„ + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ] ) .

One can then optimize over the threshold Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ to get the maximum achievable perfect secrecy rate.

Finally, we establish the asymptotic optimality of this on/off scheme as the available average transmission power PÂ¯â†’âˆâ†’Â¯ğ‘ƒ\bar{P}\to\inftyoverÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG â†’ âˆ. For the on/off power allocation policy, we have

Rs(Câ¢P)=limPÂ¯â†’âˆâˆ«Ï„*âˆâˆ«0hMlogâ¡(1+hMâ¢P1+hEâ¢P)â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhEâ¢dhM.superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ¶ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ†’Â¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğœsuperscriptsubscript0subscriptâ„ğ‘€1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒ1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€R_{s}^{(CP)}=\lim_{\bar{P}\to\infty}~{}\int_{\tau^{*}}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\log\left(\frac{1+h_{M}P}{1+h_{E}P}\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_P ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Taking Ï„*=0superscriptğœ0\tau^{*}=0italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0, we get P=PÂ¯ğ‘ƒÂ¯ğ‘ƒP=\bar{P}italic_P = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG and

Rs(Câ¢P)superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ¶ğ‘ƒ\displaystyle R_{s}^{(CP)}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_P ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥\displaystyle\geqâ‰¥ limPÂ¯â†’âˆâˆ«0âˆâˆ«0hMlogâ¡((1/PÂ¯)+hM(1/PÂ¯)+hE)â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhEâ¢dhMsubscriptâ†’Â¯ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscript0subscriptâ„ğ‘€1Â¯ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€1Â¯ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€\displaystyle\lim_{\bar{P}\to\infty}~{}\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\log\left(\frac{(1/\bar{P})+h_{M}}{(1/\bar{P})+h_{E}}\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG ( 1 / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (13)
=(a)ğ‘\displaystyle\overset{(a)}{=}start_OVERACCENT ( italic_a ) end_OVERACCENT start_ARG = end_ARG âˆ«0âˆâˆ«0hMlimPÂ¯â†’âˆlogâ¡((1/PÂ¯)+hM(1/PÂ¯)+hE)â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dâ¢hEâ¢dâ¢hMsuperscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscript0subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ†’Â¯ğ‘ƒ1Â¯ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€1Â¯ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸dsubscriptâ„ğ¸dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\lim_{\bar{P}\to\infty}~{}\log\left(\frac{(1/\bar{P})+h_{M}}{(1/\bar{P})+h_{E}}\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG ( 1 / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=\displaystyle== âˆ«0âˆâˆ«0hMlogâ¡(hMhE)â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhEâ¢dhM=ğ”¼{hM>hE}â¢{logâ¡(hMhE)},superscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscript0subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptğ”¼subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\log\left(\frac{h_{M}}{h_{E}}\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}~{}=~{}{\mathbb{E}}_{\{h_{M}>h_{E}\}}\left\{\log\left(\frac{h_{M}}{h_{E}}\right)\right\},âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) } ,

where (a) follows from the Dominated Convergence Theorem, since

|logâ¡((1/PÂ¯)+hM(1/PÂ¯)+hE)|â‰¤|logâ¡(hMhE)|,âˆ€PÂ¯whenÂ hM>hE,1Â¯ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€1Â¯ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸for-allÂ¯ğ‘ƒwhenÂ hM>hE,\left|\log\left(\frac{(1/\bar{P})+h_{M}}{(1/\bar{P})+h_{E}}\right)\right|~{}\leq~{}\left|\log\left(\frac{h_{M}}{h_{E}}\right)\right|,\qquad\forall\bar{P}\quad\mbox{when $h_{M}>h_{E}$,}| roman_log ( divide start_ARG ( 1 / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 / overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) | â‰¤ | roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) | , âˆ€ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG when italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,
andâˆ«0âˆâˆ«0hMlogâ¡(hMhE)â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhEâ¢dhM<âˆ,andsuperscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscript0subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€\mbox{and}\qquad\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\log\left(\frac{h_{M}}{h_{E}}\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}<\infty,and âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < âˆ ,

since ğ”¼â¢{hM}<âˆğ”¼subscriptâ„ğ‘€{\mathbb{E}}\{h_{M}\}<\inftyblackboard_E { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } < âˆ, |âˆ«01logâ¡xâ¢dâ¢x|=1<âˆsuperscriptsubscript01ğ‘¥dğ‘¥1\Big{|}\int_{0}^{1}\log x~{}{\mathrm{d}}x\Big{|}=1<\infty| âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_x roman_d italic_x | = 1 < âˆ and fâ¢(hM),fâ¢(hE)ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸f(h_{M}),f(h_{E})italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are continuous and bounded.

Now under the full CSI assumption, we have

Cs(F)=ğ”¼{hM>hE}â¢{logâ¡(1Pâ¢(hM,hE)+hM1Pâ¢(hM,hE)+hE)}â‰¤ğ”¼{hM>hE}â¢{logâ¡(hMhE)}.superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘ ğ¹subscriptğ”¼subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸1ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptâ„ğ‘€1ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptğ”¼subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸C_{s}^{(F)}~{}=~{}{\mathbb{E}}_{\{h_{M}>h_{E}\}}\left\{\log\left(\frac{\frac{1}{P(h_{M},h_{E})}+h_{M}}{\frac{1}{P(h_{M},h_{E})}+h_{E}}\right)\right\}~{}\leq~{}{\mathbb{E}}_{\{h_{M}>h_{E}\}}\left\{\log\left(\frac{h_{M}}{h_{E}}\right)\right\}.italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_log ( divide start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) } â‰¤ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) } . (14)

From (13) and (14), it is clear that the proposed on/off power allocation policy that uses only the main channel CSI achieves the secrecy capacity under the full CSI assumption as PÂ¯â†’âˆâ†’Â¯ğ‘ƒ\bar{P}\to\inftyoverÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG â†’ âˆ. Thus the absence of eavesdropper CSI at the transmitter does not reduce the secrecy capacity at high SNR values.

5 Numerical Results

As an additional benchmark, we first obtain the performance when the transmitter does not have any knowledge of both the main and eavesdropper channels (only receiver CSI). In this scenario, the transmitter is unable to exploit rate/power adaptation and always transmits with power PÂ¯Â¯ğ‘ƒ\bar{P}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG. It is straightforward to see that the achievable perfect secrecy rate in this scenario (using Gaussian inputs) is given by

Rs(R)superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘…\displaystyle R_{s}^{(R)}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =\displaystyle== [âˆ«0âˆâˆ«0âˆ[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢PÂ¯)âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢PÂ¯)]â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhE]+superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscript0delimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘ƒ1subscriptâ„ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸\displaystyle\left[\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{\infty}\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}\bar{P}\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}\bar{P}\right)\right]f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}\right]^{+}[ âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) ] italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=\displaystyle== [âˆ«0âˆlogâ¡(1+hMâ¢PÂ¯)â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢dhMâˆ’âˆ«0âˆlogâ¡(1+hEâ¢PÂ¯)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhE]+,superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript01subscriptâ„ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘ƒğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€superscriptsubscript01subscriptâ„ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸\displaystyle\left[\int_{0}^{\infty}\log\left(1+h_{M}\bar{P}\right)f(h_{M}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}-\int_{0}^{\infty}\log\left(1+h_{E}\bar{P}\right)f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}\right]^{+}~{},[ âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

which reduces to the following for the Rayleigh fading scenario

Rs(R)=[expâ¡(1Î³Â¯Mâ¢PÂ¯)â¢Eiâ¢(1Î³Â¯Mâ¢PÂ¯)âˆ’expâ¡(1Î³Â¯Eâ¢PÂ¯)â¢Eiâ¢(1Î³Â¯Eâ¢PÂ¯)]+.superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘…superscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘ƒEi1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘ƒ1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒEi1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒR_{s}^{(R)}~{}=~{}\left[\exp\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}\bar{P}}\right)\textrm{Ei}\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}\bar{P}}\right)-\exp\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}\bar{P}}\right)\textrm{Ei}\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}\bar{P}}\right)\right]^{+}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG ) Ei ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG ) - roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG ) Ei ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Thus when Î³Â¯Eâ‰¥Î³Â¯MsubscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€\overline{\gamma}_{E}\geq\overline{\gamma}_{M}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Rs(R)=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘…0R_{s}^{(R)}=0italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0. The results for the Rayleigh normalized-symmetric case (Î³Â¯M=Î³Â¯E=1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸1\overline{\gamma}_{M}=\overline{\gamma}_{E}=1overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1) are presented in Fig.Â 2. It is clear that the performance of the on/off power control scheme is very close to the secrecy capacity (with only main channel CSI) for a wide range of SNRs and, as expected, approaches the secrecy capacities, under both the full CSI and main channel CSI assumptions, at high values of SNR. The performance of the constant rate scheme is much worse than the other schemes that employ rate adaptation. Here we note that the performance curve for the constant rate scheme might be a lower bound to the secrecy capacity (since the KKT conditions are necessary but not sufficient for non-convex optimization). We then consider an asymmetric scenario, wherein the eavesdropper channel is more capable than the main channel, with Î³Â¯M=1subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ‘€1\overline{\gamma}_{M}=1overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and Î³Â¯E=2subscriptÂ¯ğ›¾ğ¸2\overline{\gamma}_{E}=2overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2. The performance results for this scenario are plotted in Fig.Â 3. Again it is clear from the plot that the performance of the on/off power control scheme is optimal at high values of SNR, and that rate adaptation schemes yield higher perfect secrecy rates than constant rate transmission schemes.

6 Conclusions

We have characterized the secrecy capacity of the slow fading channel with an eavesdropper under different assumptions on the available transmitter CSI. Our work establishes the interesting result that a non-zero perfectly secure rate is achievable in the fading channel even when the eavesdropper is more capable than the legitimate receiver (on the average). By contrasting this conclusion with the traditional AWGN scenario, one can see the positive impact of fading on enhancing the secrecy capacity. Furthermore, we proposed a low-complexity on/off power transmission scheme and established its asymptotic optimality. This optimality shows that the presence of eavesdropper CSI at the transmitter does not offer additional gains in the secrecy capacity for slow fading channels, at high enough SNR levels. The knowledge of the main channel CSI, however, is crucial since it is easy to see that the absence of this information leads to a zero secrecy capacity when the eavesdropper is more capable than the legitimate receiver on the average. Finally, our theoretical and numerical results established the critical role of appropriate rate adaptation in facilitating secure communications over slow fading channels.

Appendix A Proof of TheoremÂ 1

for sufficiently large nğ‘›nitalic_n. (20)

â‰¥âˆ«0âˆâˆ«0âˆ[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM,hE)1+hEâ¢Pâ¢(hM,hE))]+â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhEâˆ’2â¢Î´.absentsuperscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscript0superscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸2ğ›¿\geq\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{\infty}\left[\log\left(\frac{1+h_{M}P(h_{M},h_{E})}{1+h_{E}P(h_{M},h_{E})}\right)\right]^{+}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}~{}-~{}2\delta.â‰¥ âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 2 italic_Î´ . (21)

Combining (18) and (21), we get the desired result.

We now prove the converse part by showing that for any perfect secrecy rate Rssubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ R_{s}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with equivocation rate Re>Rsâˆ’Ïµsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘’subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ italic-ÏµR_{e}>R_{s}-\epsilonitalic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ïµ and error probability Penâ†’0â†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘›0P_{e}^{n}\rightarrow 0italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ 0 as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\inftyitalic_n â†’ âˆ, there exists a power allocation policy Pâ¢(hM,hE)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸P(h_{M},h_{E})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) satisfying the average power constraint, such that

Rsâ‰¤âˆ¬[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM,hE))âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢Pâ¢(hM,hE))]+â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhE.subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ double-integralsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸R_{s}~{}\leq~{}\iint\left[\log(1+h_{M}P(h_{M},h_{E}))-\log(1+h_{E}P(h_{M},h_{E}))\right]^{+}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ âˆ¬ [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

=\displaystyle== âˆ‘i=1nâˆ¬Iâ¢(X;Y|Z,hM,hE)â¢ğŸ{hMâ¢(i)=hM,hEâ¢(i)=hE}â¢dhMâ¢dhE+nâ¢Î´nsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›double-integralğ¼ğ‘‹conditionalğ‘Œğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸subscript1formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘›subscriptğ›¿ğ‘›\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\iint I(X;Y|Z,h_{M},h_{E}){\mathbf{1}}_{\{h_{M}(i)=h_{M},h_{E}(i)=h_{E}\}}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}+n\delta_{n}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¬ italic_I ( italic_X ; italic_Y | italic_Z , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=\displaystyle== âˆ¬Iâ¢(X;Y|Z,hM,hE)â¢Nâ¢(hM,hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhE+nâ¢Î´ndouble-integralğ¼ğ‘‹conditionalğ‘Œğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘›subscriptğ›¿ğ‘›\displaystyle\iint I(X;Y|Z,h_{M},h_{E})N(h_{M},h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}+n\delta_{n}âˆ¬ italic_I ( italic_X ; italic_Y | italic_Z , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_N ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
â‰¤(d)ğ‘‘\displaystyle\overset{(d)}{\leq}start_OVERACCENT ( italic_d ) end_OVERACCENT start_ARG â‰¤ end_ARG âˆ¬Nâ¢(hM,hE)â¢[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pnâ¢(hM,hE))âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢Pnâ¢(hM,hE))]+â¢dhMâ¢dhE+nâ¢Î´n.double-integralğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸superscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸1subscriptâ„ğ¸superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘›subscriptğ›¿ğ‘›\displaystyle\iint N(h_{M},h_{E})\left[\log(1+h_{M}P^{n}(h_{M},h_{E}))-\log(1+h_{E}P^{n}(h_{M},h_{E}))\right]^{+}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}+n\delta_{n}.âˆ¬ italic_N ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

In the above derivation, (a) follows from the Fano inequality, (b) follows from the data processing inequality since Wâ†’Xnâ†’(Yn,Zn)â†’ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›â†’superscriptğ‘Œğ‘›superscriptğ‘ğ‘›W\to X^{n}\to(Y^{n},Z^{n})italic_W â†’ italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) forms a Markov chain, (c) follows from the fact that conditioning reduces entropy and from the memoryless property of the channel, (d) follows from the fact that given hMsubscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hEsubscriptâ„ğ¸h_{E}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the fading channel reduces to an AWGN channel with channel gains (hM,hE)subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸(h_{M},h_{E})( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and average transmission power Pnâ¢(hM,hE)superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸P^{n}(h_{M},h_{E})italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), for which

Iâ¢(X;Y|Z,hM,hE)â‰¤[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pnâ¢(hM,hE))âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢Pnâ¢(hM,hE))]+,ğ¼ğ‘‹conditionalğ‘Œğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸superscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸1subscriptâ„ğ¸superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸I(X;Y|Z,h_{M},h_{E})~{}\leq~{}\left[\log(1+h_{M}P^{n}(h_{M},h_{E}))-\log(1+h_{E}P^{n}(h_{M},h_{E}))\right]^{+}~{},italic_I ( italic_X ; italic_Y | italic_Z , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

as shown in [5, 6]. Since the codewords satisfy the power constraint, we have

âˆ¬Pnâ¢(hM,hE)â¢(Nâ¢(hM,hE)n)â¢dhMâ¢dhEâ‰¤PÂ¯.double-integralsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘›differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒ\iint P^{n}(h_{M},h_{E})\left(\frac{N(h_{M},h_{E})}{n}\right){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}~{}\leq~{}\bar{P}.âˆ¬ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( divide start_ARG italic_N ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG .

For any hM,hEsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸h_{M},h_{E}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that fâ¢(hM,hE)â‰ 0ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸0f(h_{M},h_{E})\neq 0italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰  0, {Pnâ¢(hM,hE)}superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸\{P^{n}(h_{M},h_{E})\}{ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } are bounded sequences in nğ‘›nitalic_n. Thus there exists a subsequence that converges to a limit Pâ¢(hM,hE)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸P(h_{M},h_{E})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\inftyitalic_n â†’ âˆ. Since for each nğ‘›nitalic_n, the power constraint is satisfied, we have

âˆ¬Pâ¢(hM,hE)â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhEâ‰¤PÂ¯.double-integralğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸Â¯ğ‘ƒ\iint P(h_{M},h_{E})f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}~{}\leq~{}\bar{P}.âˆ¬ italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG . (23)

Now, we have

Reâ‰¤âˆ¬Nâ¢(hM,hE)nâ¢[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pnâ¢(hM,hE)1+hEâ¢Pnâ¢(hM,hE))]+â¢dhMâ¢dhE+Î´n.subscriptğ‘…ğ‘’double-integralğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘›superscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸1subscriptâ„ğ¸superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptğ›¿ğ‘›R_{e}~{}\leq~{}\iint\frac{N(h_{M},h_{E})}{n}\left[\log\left(\frac{1+h_{M}P^{n}(h_{M},h_{E})}{1+h_{E}P^{n}(h_{M},h_{E})}\right)\right]^{+}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}+\delta_{n}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ âˆ¬ divide start_ARG italic_N ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG [ roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Taking the limit along the convergent subsequence and using the ergodicity of the channel, we get

Reâ‰¤âˆ¬[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM,hE)1+hEâ¢Pâ¢(hM,hE))]+â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhE+Î´n.subscriptğ‘…ğ‘’double-integralsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptğ›¿ğ‘›R_{e}~{}\leq~{}\iint\left[\log\left(\frac{1+h_{M}P(h_{M},h_{E})}{1+h_{E}P(h_{M},h_{E})}\right)\right]^{+}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}+\delta_{n}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ âˆ¬ [ roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

The claim is thus proved.

Appendix B Proof of TheoremÂ 2

Let Rs=Cs(M)âˆ’Î´subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘ ğ‘€ğ›¿R_{s}=C_{s}^{(M)}-\deltaitalic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_M ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î´ for some small Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0italic_Î´ > 0. Let n=n1â¢mğ‘›subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘šn=n_{1}mitalic_n = italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m, where n1subscriptğ‘›1n_{1}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the number of symbols transmitted in each coherence interval, and mğ‘šmitalic_m represents the number of coherence intervals over which the message Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is transmitted. Let R=ğ”¼â¢{logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM))}âˆ’Ïµğ‘…ğ”¼1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€italic-ÏµR={\mathbb{E}}\{\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M})\right)\}-\epsilonitalic_R = blackboard_E { roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) } - italic_Ïµ. We first generate all binary sequences {ğ•}ğ•\{{\mathbf{V}}\}{ bold_V } of length nâ¢Rğ‘›ğ‘…nRitalic_n italic_R and then independently assign each of them randomly to one of 2nâ¢Rssuperscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ 2^{nR_{s}}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT groups, according to a uniform distribution. This ensures that any of the sequences are equally likely to be within any of the groups. Each secret message wâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,2nâ¢Rs}ğ‘¤1â‹¯superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ w\in\{1,\cdots,2^{nR_{s}}\}italic_w âˆˆ { 1 , â‹¯ , 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } is then assigned a group ğ•â¢(w)ğ•ğ‘¤{\mathbf{V}}(w)bold_V ( italic_w ). In the above derivation, (a) follows from the memoryless property of the channel and the independence of the Xn1â¢(i)superscriptğ‘‹subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘–X^{n_{1}}(i)italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i )â€™s, (b) is obtained by removing all those terms which correspond to the coherence intervals iâˆ‰ğ’©mğ‘–subscriptğ’©ğ‘ši\notin{\mathcal{N}}_{m}italic_i âˆ‰ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ğ’©m={iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,m}:hMâ¢(i)>hEâ¢(i)}subscriptğ’©ğ‘šconditional-setğ‘–1â‹¯ğ‘šsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘–{\mathcal{N}}_{m}=\left\{i\in\{1,\cdots,m\}:h_{M}(i)>h_{E}(i)\right\}caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_i âˆˆ { 1 , â‹¯ , italic_m } : italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) }, and (c) follows from the ergodicity of the channel as mâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘šm\to\inftyitalic_m â†’ âˆ.
