In this list decoding, at coherence interval iğ‘–iitalic_i, the eavesdropper first constructs a list â„’isubscriptâ„’ğ‘–{\mathcal{L}}_{i}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that xn1â¢(i)âˆˆâ„’isuperscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘–subscriptâ„’ğ‘–x^{n_{1}}(i)\in{\mathcal{L}}_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) âˆˆ caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if (xn1â¢(i),zn1â¢(i))superscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘–superscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘–(x^{n_{1}}(i),z^{n_{1}}(i))( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) , italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) ) are jointly typical. Let â„’=â„’1Ã—â„’2Ã—â‹¯Ã—â„’mâ„’subscriptâ„’1subscriptâ„’2â‹¯subscriptâ„’ğ‘š{\mathcal{L}}={\mathcal{L}}_{1}\times{\mathcal{L}}_{2}\times\cdots\times{\mathcal{L}}_{m}caligraphic_L = caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— â‹¯ Ã— caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Given wğ‘¤witalic_w, the eavesdropper declares that x^n=(xn1â¢(1),â‹¯,xn1â¢(m))superscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘›superscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘›11â‹¯superscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘š\hat{x}^{n}=(x^{n_{1}}(1),\cdots,x^{n_{1}}(m))over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) , â‹¯ , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) ) was transmitted, if x^nsuperscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘›\hat{x}^{n}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the only codeword such that x^nâˆˆBâ¢(w)âˆ©â„’superscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘›ğµğ‘¤â„’\hat{x}^{n}\in B(w)\cap{\mathcal{L}}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_B ( italic_w ) âˆ© caligraphic_L, where Bâ¢(w)ğµğ‘¤B(w)italic_B ( italic_w ) is the set of codewords corresponding to the message wğ‘¤witalic_w. If the eavesdropper finds none or more than one such sequence, then it declares an error. Hence, there are two type of error events: 1) â„°1subscriptâ„°1{\mathcal{E}}_{1}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: the transmitted codeword xtnsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘¡x^{n}_{t}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not in â„’â„’{\mathcal{L}}caligraphic_L, 2) â„°2subscriptâ„°2{\mathcal{E}}_{2}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: âˆƒxnâ‰ xtnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘¡\exists x^{n}\neq x^{n}_{t}âˆƒ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that xnâˆˆBâ¢(w)âˆ©â„’superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğµğ‘¤â„’x^{n}\in B(w)\cap{\mathcal{L}}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_B ( italic_w ) âˆ© caligraphic_L. Thus the error probability Prâ¢(x^nâ‰ xtn)=Prâ¢(â„°1âˆªâ„°2)â‰¤Prâ¢(â„°1)+Prâ¢(â„°2)Prsuperscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘¡Prsubscriptâ„°1subscriptâ„°2Prsubscriptâ„°1Prsubscriptâ„°2\textrm{Pr}(\hat{x}^{n}\neq x^{n}_{t})=\textrm{Pr}({\mathcal{E}}_{1}\cup{\mathcal{E}}_{2})\leq\textrm{Pr}({\mathcal{E}}_{1})+\textrm{Pr}({\mathcal{E}}_{2})Pr ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = Pr ( caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ Pr ( caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + Pr ( caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Based on the AEP, we know that Prâ¢(â„°1)â‰¤Ïµ1Prsubscriptâ„°1subscriptitalic-Ïµ1\textrm{Pr}({\mathcal{E}}_{1})\leq\epsilon_{1}Pr ( caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We let

Ï•iâ¢(xn1â¢(i)|zn1â¢(i))={1,whenÂ (xn1â¢(i),zn1â¢(i))Â are jointly typical,0,otherwise.subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–conditionalsuperscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘–superscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘–cases1whenÂ (xn1â¢(i),zn1â¢(i))Â are jointly typical,0otherwise.\displaystyle\phi_{i}(x^{n_{1}}(i)|z^{n_{1}}(i))~{}=~{}\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}1,&\textrm{when $(x^{n_{1}}(i),z^{n_{1}}(i))$ are jointly typical,}\\ 0,&\textrm{otherwise.}\end{array}\right.italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) ) = { start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL 1 , end_CELL start_CELL when ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) , italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) ) are jointly typical, end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 , end_CELL start_CELL otherwise. end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY (27)

=\displaystyle== 2âˆ’nâ¢(Rsâˆ’1mâ¢âˆ‘i=1m([logâ¡(1+hMâ¢(i)â¢Pâ¢(hMâ¢(i)))âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢(i)â¢Pâ¢(hMâ¢(i)))]++1n1)+|ğ’©m|â¢Ïµm),superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ 1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘–1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘–ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ’©ğ‘šitalic-Ïµğ‘š\displaystyle 2^{-n\left(R_{s}-\frac{1}{m}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{m}\left(\left[\log(1+h_{M}(i)P(h_{M}(i)))-\log(1+h_{E}(i)P(h_{M}(i)))\right]^{+}+\frac{1}{n_{1}}\right)+\frac{|{\mathcal{N}}_{m}|\epsilon}{m}\right)},2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_n ( italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) + divide start_ARG | caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where (a) follows from the uniform distribution of the codewords in Bâ¢(w)ğµğ‘¤B(w)italic_B ( italic_w ). Now as n1â†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘›1n_{1}\to\inftyitalic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ âˆ and mâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘šm\to\inftyitalic_m â†’ âˆ, we get

Prâ¢(â„°2)â‰¤2âˆ’nâ¢(Csâˆ’Î´âˆ’Cs+câ¢Ïµ)=2âˆ’nâ¢(câ¢Ïµâˆ’Î´),Prsubscriptâ„°2superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ¶ğ‘ ğ›¿subscriptğ¶ğ‘ ğ‘italic-Ïµsuperscript2ğ‘›ğ‘italic-Ïµğ›¿\textrm{Pr}({\mathcal{E}}_{2})~{}\leq~{}2^{-n\left(C_{s}-\delta-C_{s}+c\epsilon\right)}~{}=~{}2^{-n(c\epsilon-\delta)},Pr ( caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_n ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î´ - italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c italic_Ïµ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_n ( italic_c italic_Ïµ - italic_Î´ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where c=Prâ¢(hM>hE)ğ‘Prsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸c=\textrm{Pr}(h_{M}>h_{E})italic_c = Pr ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Thus, by choosing Ïµ>(Î´/c)italic-Ïµğ›¿ğ‘\epsilon>(\delta/c)italic_Ïµ > ( italic_Î´ / italic_c ), the error probability Prâ¢(â„°2)â†’0â†’Prsubscriptâ„°20\textrm{Pr}({\mathcal{E}}_{2})\to 0Pr ( caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â†’ 0 as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\to\inftyitalic_n â†’ âˆ. Now using Fanoâ€™s inequality, we get

Hâ¢(Xn1â¢(1),â‹¯,Xn1â¢(m)|W,Zn1â¢(1),â‹¯,Zn1â¢(m),hMn,hEn)â‰¤nâ¢Î´nâ†’0asÂ nâ†’âˆ.ğ»superscriptğ‘‹subscriptğ‘›11â‹¯conditionalsuperscriptğ‘‹subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘šğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘›11â‹¯superscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘›ğ‘›subscriptğ›¿ğ‘›â†’absent0asÂ nâ†’âˆH(X^{n_{1}}(1),\cdots,X^{n_{1}}(m)|W,Z^{n_{1}}(1),\cdots,Z^{n_{1}}(m),h_{M}^{n},h_{E}^{n})~{}\leq~{}n\delta_{n}\qquad\mbox{$\to 0$}\qquad\mbox{as $n\to\infty$}.italic_H ( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) , â‹¯ , italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) | italic_W , italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) , â‹¯ , italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_n italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ 0 as italic_n â†’ âˆ .

Combining this with (24), we get the desired result.

For the converse part, consider any sequence of (2nâ¢Rs,n)superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘›(2^{nR_{s}},n)( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_n ) codes with perfect secrecy rate Rssubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ R_{s}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and equivocation rate Resubscriptğ‘…ğ‘’R_{e}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such that Re>Rsâˆ’Ïµsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘’subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ italic-ÏµR_{e}>R_{s}-\epsilonitalic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ïµ, with average power less than or equal to PÂ¯Â¯ğ‘ƒ\bar{P}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG and error probability Penâ†’0â†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘›0P_{e}^{n}\to 0italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ 0 as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\inftyitalic_n â†’ âˆ. We follow the same steps used in the proof of the converse in TheoremÂ 1 with the only difference that now the transmission power Pn(.)P^{n}(.)italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( . ) only depends on hMsubscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. From (A), we get

This follows from the fact that given hMsubscriptâ„ğ‘€h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hEsubscriptâ„ğ¸h_{E}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the fading channel reduces to an AWGN channel with channel gains (hM,hE)subscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptâ„ğ¸(h_{M},h_{E})( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and average transmission power Pnâ¢(hM)superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptâ„ğ‘€P^{n}(h_{M})italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), for which Gaussian inputs are known to be optimal [5, 6].

Similar to the proof of TheoremÂ 1, we take the limit over the convergent subsequence and use the ergodicity of the channel to obtain

Reâ‰¤âˆ¬[logâ¡(1+hMâ¢Pâ¢(hM))âˆ’logâ¡(1+hEâ¢Pâ¢(hM))]+â¢fâ¢(hM)â¢fâ¢(hE)â¢dhMâ¢dhE+Î´n,subscriptğ‘…ğ‘’double-integralsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€1subscriptâ„ğ¸ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptâ„ğ¸differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ‘€differential-dsubscriptâ„ğ¸subscriptğ›¿ğ‘›\displaystyle R_{e}\leq\iint\left[\log(1+h_{M}P(h_{M}))-\log(1+h_{E}P(h_{M}))\right]^{+}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}+\delta_{n},italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ âˆ¬ [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (31)

where ğ”¼â¢{Pâ¢(hM)}â‰¤PÂ¯ğ”¼ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘ƒ{\mathbb{E}}\{P(h_{M})\}\leq\bar{P}blackboard_E { italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } â‰¤ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG. The claim is thus proved.
